content:
I feel like at this point I've said everything I can about the topic. Your first paragraph seems to pretty much hit the nail on the head. 

Directly realizing all of this time business only comes about from an immense mental stillness. Really all you can do is wait and watch. Mediation can help

things can happen without you experiencing them
your direct experience is identical to a scenario where the universe started exactly right now. there is nothing in your experience that suggests you actually have had past experiences before
sure you can say "there was no one there to experience it," but at the same time there isnt anyone here right now to experience "your own experience" there is just the experience itself
as for what caused the memory to exist... bro how could i know? why do any of the senses exist? why does anything else exist? beyond me

tldr: i am saying that you experience no duration, so it doesnt make sense for you to believe that you had an experience in the past

yeah thats a reasonable thing to try as a screen
but at no point should the screen ever believe "the thing im displaying now is literally what is displayed in 1 hour" since all it can display now is what is on it now
as i understand it, those two things are actually very different even though they taste similar

the boltzmann brain is "you cant be sure what the outside world really is"
all this business about time is "under no circumstance does it ever make sense to say you have a real personal relationship with a memory, or that you actually experienced a past thing that you remember"
all this business about time is not denying the existence of past events, but it is to say that you did not experience them since your only existence is of the blip exactly right now
mmmm
i agree

why is it necessary to refer to yourself if you are always exactly aware of yourself?

itd be like if a tv was trying to figure out what it was displaying so then it allocates a corner of the screen to trying to represent the rest of the screen when thats completely unnecessary because what its displaying is exactly what its displaying

seems like a pretty useful abstraction to me
however it is clear in the way you described it that the you are not this abstraction since it is something that is seem from the reference point rather than being the reference point itself
what exactly does "reference point" refer to?

i dont know how to answer the question
it sort of just does
yeah quite unsatisfying

there is a life
there is a body
it is not "my body"
it is not "my life"
it is just body
and life

thank you for listening to my segment of the slam poetry event

They're similar but not quite the same. Seeing a thought without any identification is a clarity that can be momentary or permanent. SR is realizing thoughts can't ever have a personal relationship with a "me" because the "me" that one originally believed oneself to be was also just another thought that isn't fundamentally different from any other thought. SR makes the clarity of no identification permanent

The important part is seeing the relationship between thought and the other senses which the 5 main senses are still relevant to
We do tend to get muddled up in thought because our social world is more or less all made of thoughts

Your life and your perspective are not related to what you actually are which is why they don't need to be explained to understand yourself. Believing that there is a "my life" rather than just "life" is itself the error self-inquiry is meant to examine. 

You already have all the necessary information because *the fact that you don't experience duration at all* is always apparent in your experience, but you don't know where in your experience to look. Non-dualists are merely attempting to point your attention to something that is already in your experience but is misunderstood by your thought faculty.

this is a narrative you have constructed about your experience that involves time, which is totally valid

however within your own direct experience of vision, for example, there is absolutely nothing about the time it takes light to travel to reach your eye, there is just whatever thing you see with no aspect of time at all

again, im not saying time doesnt exist. time is a fantastic way of understanding the world. im saying that the only relationship you personally have with time is your ability to invent it. there is no dimension of time through your 5 main senses

I suppose talking more about this won't really do much
You sort of need to dive down into your own experience by yourself and actually look for the time in your experience
On the other hand shouldn't having experience of the past and future be inaccessible?

I suppose I should clarify that I'm not saying time doesn't exist
I'm saying you don't experience it
The actions happening over time is totally a thing but you have no experience of the duration only the now

It doesn't 
My own statement to you was also an invention

Everything you have just described to me is thinking's ability to invent a perception of motion/time

I suppose my challenge to you would be to find the literal direct experience of time independent of mental constructs
What is meant by "every perception that informs an experience is an action"? I thought that experience is just experience in the way that blue is indescribable to a blind person

The task seems Herculean because you are approaching it from the perspective of building a mental model. You say the now is too speedy but the now doesn't move at all. It is your thoughts that create the illusion of motion. The now cannot be understood by thinking, it is literally just experience without narration and that is it. The point is to stop trying to think about it because it's not possible to. 

Mediation may make observing the now easier, but whether that's the best way for you? I have no idea

yeah i think so too
i didnt make it clear that my point wasnt that your memories are what make you, you... so thats on me ðŸ’€

sure its wild but i think it was reasonable for him to say that, since my communication was a bit clunky and the most reasonable way to interpret my communication is just an incorrect understanding of the analogy
so good work @nymandus66

Again that wasn't the point I was getting at, but I don't think that's on you I think that's on me for not clarifying what "thesis", so to speak, I was actually defending. I am not saying that the alien literally becomes you when it downloads "your memories". I am saying that both you and the alien are wrong to believe you have any personal relationship with the past through memory at all. 

I think that analogy is good thinking and pretty much complete disproves that the alien becomes you when it downloads "your memories". 

Within this analogy, there is the assumption of experience having duration. When you examine your own experience very closely, can you actually feel this duration? The problem of who is who when the door opens completely disappears if there is no possibility of a self existing for a duration, since experience has no duration either (whoops gave away what I believe the answer the my own question is).

Firstly I think it's good that you are not taking what I say as authority and doing the inquiry yourself. Don't take what I say as being absolutely true. I'm just some random guy on the internet. There is also the possibility that I miscommunicate something out of carelessness, like having an extra "not" somewhere in a sentence which messes everything up. 

The point of the alien analogy was not to say that the alien is you. The point is that when you have personal identification with your own memories, you are doing literally the exact same thing that the alien is doing, which is mistaking the subject inside of the memory as yourself. You and the alien both have the exact same relationship to "your memories" (which aren't actually yours at all). Since it is obviously incorrect that the alien is the one who was there to experience the remembered past event, it is meant to become intuitive that you were not either. 

Imagine that *right now* you have suddenly been placed in Schro Cat's body with all of its functions and memories fully intact. What I am saying is that is actually what your direct experience is, so it makes no sense for you to have a personal relationship with past events you did not experience.

There is a possibility that your absolute certainty in your conclusion is what is stopping your progress 

It is true that you can't not know your experience, but there is still the possibility that that you believe about your experience is not actually what you experience
Crazy

literally me rn
hehe

the cage the elephant version is alright

gpt says body mirroring is part of empathy, how epic
Thanks for sharing regardless ðŸ˜Š

I find it overstimulating

Someone's probably already done some research on it

What? Really? Crazy
I wonder if I had a completely prosthetic body, would my capacity for empathy change? How much does empathy have to do with the body? That's for me to explore
Nah it's all good I'll listen to it on my own in a moment
Where did the first ADHD related quote come from
Very sad
I will pay attention to this more too
Describing motivation as such is very interesting

Very well could be the case with ADHD
That quote feels super deep, nice quote

This makes a lot of sense 
The direct experience is literally only "sitting right now" but we make it worse by imagining the painful future hours when that isn't necessary at all
What forced you to stop waiting? What do you mean by that
Makes sense
Trigger what?
I see

I didn't use a timer
Yeah it's just sitting there without an agenda. Not waiting for anything to happen

@nymandus66 @itsneekeetah 
ig the overall relevance meditation has to self-inquiry is that the whole process of self-inquiry is "figure out what your own experience actually is," and meditation is just the attentive watching of the experience. sitting down with your eyes closed just happens to remove distractions so its easier to stay attentive

nope
my mind is more silent than it used to be and there are some short periods of complete silence but its never reliably silent at the end
how to make songs go away? no idea. i was never able to make them go away. i just sat there with the song. theyre actually alright company :)

honestly not sure
i just sat down with my eyes closed the same time every night and my mind just became clearer.
when i say i reccomend people do meditation im trying to get other people the same mysterious benefit that i got. i noticed that it was extremely important to make it the same time every day because it forced me to be aware of how i was spending my time throughout the day to make sure i actually could respect my own meditation time slot. 

i think meditation reduces mental activity and increases awareness in some connected way that i dont know how to explain. thats very helpful for inquiry because when certain mental processes cease, it becomes infinitely easier to understand some of the stuff jamie says like "thought is just another sensory perception occurring now" because you literally just observe it to be true. 

the biggest thing for me personally was when i could *literally directly observe/feel* that it wasnt possible to think about myself. im guessing that feeling was caused by the "this thought is me!" thought pattern temporarily shutting off and for the first time i could clearly see what a thought actually is without any identification on top. on this server we do a lot of logical arguing but i think that for nearly all people that is almost completely useless for self-realization. the type of understanding that self-realization actually is, is not one that can be thought about or explained.
from your perspective or just from first person perspective? the alien would claim that it was actually him who was there

When you read your history textbook it is a sensory perception now. It does have a relationship with the past because it recounts what happened, but no matter how deeply you know that textbook, you did not experience the events that it recounts. Those events have no personal relationship to you. 

Memory works exactly like reading that textbook. When you remember an event it is a sensory perception now. It does have a relationship with the past because it recounts what happened, but no matter how deeply you know that memory, you did not experience the events that it recounts. Those events have no personal relationship to you. 

Your own relationship with "your own past" is fundamentally no different to your relationship with the textbook's recount of the past.

You actually just talked about memory twice instead of talking about vision once and memory once. Your examine of vision is of a memory of a vision. 

I mean that when vision is currently being experienced, there is no question of who is experiencing it. It is your own present sense perception. When you experience memory, it should be the exact same way, it is your own present sense perception. The confusion starts when you believe that the memory *really does represent a past sensory perception*, when all it is is just another sense perception happening now. The question of "who was there" isn't answerable because there isn't a "there" in at all. 

I never found any of this stuff to make sense intellectually until doing meditation, so I reccomend giving meditation a try if you haven't already.
this is touched on in the last paragraph of the massive text wall i just sent

this question is exactly what jamie's alien analogy is attempting to address
Here is Jamie's alien analogy: "I think a good way to point to our misunderstanding of our relationship with time is to imagine thereâ€™s an alien who wants to experience what itâ€™s like to be a human. The alien takes you and plugs some wires into your brain and says, Iâ€™m going to take over your consciousness for a second to download your memory. Ok close your eyes, and in 10 seconds Iâ€™m going to take over. Ok 3 2 1 Iâ€™m opening my eyes as a human for the first time. Huh, weird. feet huh?â€ and they swap back having downloaded the data and the alien says thanks, I understand you now. You might say â€œwhat, thatâ€™s it? How can you know what itâ€™s like to be me, I had to go through years of self-improvement to get where I am now. I was bullied in school and had two terrible relationships before figuring out who I am nowâ€ â€œyeah I know it was in your memoryâ€ â€œwhat no, it took like half my life to go through thatâ€ â€œyeah dude I was literally you I knowâ€ â€œno but you canâ€™t know what it was like you didnâ€™t experience it you just sat there, what does it feel like for someone to break up with you?â€ â€œFeels bad manâ€ â€œwhat, but it didnâ€™t happen to youâ€ â€œbro, I was literally you. I knew exactly what you know now. Itâ€™s in your memoriesâ€ â€œwhat, but. You didnâ€™tâ€¦ you werenâ€™t thereâ€."

Does any identification with a memory make sense if the alien could always claim "nonono that was me there, that wasn't actually you?" What would make your argument for really being there stronger than the alien's? 

This isn't to say that you can't be sure who was there. It's to say that the question of "who was there" isn't coherent in the first place. You don't ask "who was there" when you experience the sense perception of vision. The question of "who was there" is equally as valid for memory as it is for vision because both are sense perceptions occurring now.

it just was
what kind of answer are you looking for?

@nymandus66 
I think this is a very good response. Probably better than what I would have said lol. 

"You can't think about the past" means that the second thing listed by mr.niceguy, that it seems that you can actually re experience sensory perception of the past isn't possible. It's all now. A thought about the past is it's own thing occurring now 
Since you are the sensory perception right now and only exactly right now, you have no personal relationship with the past, which is the reason why you are not your self-image since the self-image is all past accumulations.
